trans-unit.source: <properties pageTitle="Azure App Service plans in-depth overview" description="Learn how App Service plans for Azure App Service work, and how they benefit your management experience."
trans-unit.target: <properties pageTitle="Azure App Service plans in-depth overview" description="Learn how App Service plans for Azure App Service work, and how they benefit your management experience."

trans-unit.source: <tags ms.service="app-service" ms.workload="web" ms.tgt_pltfrm="na" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.date="03/24/2015" ms.author="byvinyal"/>
trans-unit.target: <tags ms.service="app-service" ms.workload="web" ms.tgt_pltfrm="na" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.date="03/24/2015" ms.author="byvinyal"/>

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service plans in-depth overview
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service plans in-depth overview

trans-unit.source: represents a set of features and capacity that you can share across multiple apps in
trans-unit.target: represents a set of features and capacity that you can share across multiple apps in

trans-unit.source: , including Web Apps, Mobile Apps, Logic Apps or API Apps.
trans-unit.target: , including Web Apps, Mobile Apps, Logic Apps or API Apps.

trans-unit.source: ) where each tier has its own capabilities and capacity.
trans-unit.target: ) where each tier has its own capabilities and capacity.

trans-unit.source: Apps in the same subscription and geographic location can share a plan.
trans-unit.target: Apps in the same subscription and geographic location can share a plan.

trans-unit.source: All the apps sharing a plan can leverage all the capabilities and features defined by the plan's tier.
trans-unit.target: All the apps sharing a plan can leverage all the capabilities and features defined by the plan's tier.

trans-unit.source: All apps associated with a given plan run on the resources defined by the plan.
trans-unit.target: All apps associated with a given plan run on the resources defined by the plan.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your plan is configured to use two "small" instances in the standard service tier, all apps associated with that plan will run on both instances and will have access to the standard service tier functionality.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your plan is configured to use two "small" instances in the standard service tier, all apps associated with that plan will run on both instances and will have access to the standard service tier functionality.

trans-unit.source: Plan instances on which apps are running on are fully managed and highly available.
trans-unit.target: Plan instances on which apps are running on are fully managed and highly available.

trans-unit.source: In this article we'll explore the key characteristics such as tier and scale of an App Service plan and how they come into play while managing your apps.
trans-unit.target: In this article we'll explore the key characteristics such as tier and scale of an App Service plan and how they come into play while managing your apps.

trans-unit.source: An app in App Service can be associated with only one App Service plan at any given time.
trans-unit.target: An app in App Service can be associated with only one App Service plan at any given time.

trans-unit.source: Both apps and plans are contained in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Both apps and plans are contained in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: A resource group serves as the life-cycle boundary for every resource contained within it.
trans-unit.target: A resource group serves as the life-cycle boundary for every resource contained within it.

trans-unit.source: Resource groups enable you to manage all the pieces of an application together.
trans-unit.target: Resource groups enable you to manage all the pieces of an application together.

trans-unit.source: The ability to have multiple App Service plans in a single resource group allows you to allocate different apps to different physical resources.
trans-unit.target: The ability to have multiple App Service plans in a single resource group allows you to allocate different apps to different physical resources.

trans-unit.source: For example, this allows separation of resources between dev, test and production environments.
trans-unit.target: For example, this allows separation of resources between dev, test and production environments.

trans-unit.source: A scenario for this is when you might want to allocate one plan with its own dedicated set of resources for your production apps, and a second plan for your dev and test environments.
trans-unit.target: A scenario for this is when you might want to allocate one plan with its own dedicated set of resources for your production apps, and a second plan for your dev and test environments.

trans-unit.source: In this way, load testing against a new version of your apps will not compete for the same resources as your production apps, which are serving real customers.
trans-unit.target: In this way, load testing against a new version of your apps will not compete for the same resources as your production apps, which are serving real customers.

trans-unit.source: Having multiple plans in a single resource group also enables you to define an application that spans across geographical regions.
trans-unit.target: Having multiple plans in a single resource group also enables you to define an application that spans across geographical regions.

trans-unit.source: For example, a highly available app running in two regions will include two plans, one for each region, and one app associated with each plan.
trans-unit.target: For example, a highly available app running in two regions will include two plans, one for each region, and one app associated with each plan.

trans-unit.source: In such a situation, all the copies of the app will be associated with a single resource group.
trans-unit.target: In such a situation, all the copies of the app will be associated with a single resource group.

trans-unit.source: Having a single view of a resource group with multiple plans and multiple apps makes it easy to manage, control and view the health of the application.
trans-unit.target: Having a single view of a resource group with multiple plans and multiple apps makes it easy to manage, control and view the health of the application.

trans-unit.source: Create a new App Service plan vs. use an existing plan
trans-unit.target: Create a new App Service plan vs. use an existing plan

trans-unit.source: When creating a new app, you should consider creating a new resource group when the app you are about to create represents a brand new project.
trans-unit.target: When creating a new app, you should consider creating a new resource group when the app you are about to create represents a brand new project.

trans-unit.source: In this case, creating a new resource group, plan, and app is the right choice.
trans-unit.target: In this case, creating a new resource group, plan, and app is the right choice.

trans-unit.source: If the app you are about to create is a component for a larger application, then this web app should be created within the resource group allocated for that larger application.
trans-unit.target: If the app you are about to create is a component for a larger application, then this web app should be created within the resource group allocated for that larger application.

trans-unit.source: Regardless of the new app being a altogether new application or part of a larger one, you can choose to leverage an existing App Service plan to host it or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Regardless of the new app being a altogether new application or part of a larger one, you can choose to leverage an existing App Service plan to host it or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: This is more a question of capacity and expected load.
trans-unit.target: This is more a question of capacity and expected load.

trans-unit.source: If this new app is going to be resource intensive and have different scaling factors than the other apps hosted in an existing plan, it is recommended to isolate it into its own plan.
trans-unit.target: If this new app is going to be resource intensive and have different scaling factors than the other apps hosted in an existing plan, it is recommended to isolate it into its own plan.

trans-unit.source: Creating a new plan allows you to allocate a new set of resource for your web app, and provides you with greater control over resource allocation, as each plan gets its own set of instances.
trans-unit.target: Creating a new plan allows you to allocate a new set of resource for your web app, and provides you with greater control over resource allocation, as each plan gets its own set of instances.

trans-unit.source: Having the capacity to move apps across plans also allows you to change the way resources are allocated across the bigger application.
trans-unit.target: Having the capacity to move apps across plans also allows you to change the way resources are allocated across the bigger application.

trans-unit.source: Finally, if you want to create a new app in a different region, and that region doesn't have an existing plan, you will have to create a new plan in that region to be able to host your app there.
trans-unit.target: Finally, if you want to create a new app in a different region, and that region doesn't have an existing plan, you will have to create a new plan in that region to be able to host your app there.

trans-unit.source: You can't create an empty App Service plan.
trans-unit.target: You can't create an empty App Service plan.

trans-unit.source: However, you can explicitly create a new plan during app creation.
trans-unit.target: However, you can explicitly create a new plan during app creation.

trans-unit.source: You can then select or create the App Service plan for the new app.
trans-unit.target: You can then select or create the App Service plan for the new app.

trans-unit.source: Assign an app to an App Service plan
trans-unit.target: Assign an app to an App Service plan

trans-unit.source: Apps can be assigned to an existing plan during the creation process.
trans-unit.target: Apps can be assigned to an existing plan during the creation process.

trans-unit.source: You can then select or create the App Service plan for the new app.
trans-unit.target: You can then select or create the App Service plan for the new app.

trans-unit.source: will give you the list of existing plan you can choose from.
trans-unit.target: will give you the list of existing plan you can choose from.

trans-unit.target: Move an app to a different App Service plan

trans-unit.source: You can move an app to a different app service plan in the
trans-unit.target: You can move an app to a different app service plan in the

trans-unit.source: Apps can be moved between plans in the same geographical region.
trans-unit.target: Apps can be moved between plans in the same geographical region.

trans-unit.source: To move an app to another plan, navigate to the app you want to move, then click
trans-unit.target: To move an app to another plan, navigate to the app you want to move, then click

trans-unit.source: This will open the App Service Plan blade.
trans-unit.target: This will open the App Service Plan blade.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you can either pick an existing plan, or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you can either pick an existing plan, or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Plans in a different geographical location are grayed out and cannot be selected.
trans-unit.target: Plans in a different geographical location are grayed out and cannot be selected.

trans-unit.source: Note that each plan has its own pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: Note that each plan has its own pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: App Service plans represent a set of features and capacity that you can share across your apps.
trans-unit.target: App Service plans represent a set of features and capacity that you can share across your apps.

trans-unit.source: App Service plans give you the flexibility to allocate specific apps to a given set of resources and further optimize you Azure resource utilization.
trans-unit.target: App Service plans give you the flexibility to allocate specific apps to a given set of resources and further optimize you Azure resource utilization.

trans-unit.source: This way, if you want to save money on your testing environment you can share a plan across multiple apps.
trans-unit.target: This way, if you want to save money on your testing environment you can share a plan across multiple apps.

trans-unit.source: You can also maximize throughput for your production environment by scaling it across multiple regions and plans.
trans-unit.target: You can also maximize throughput for your production environment by scaling it across multiple regions and plans.
